body: The h5 file found in evaluation-results is after network evaluation only. To create a labeled video, make sure you run `deeplabcut.analyze_videos` first; this will produce a h5 data file along the video.

> The h5 file found in evaluation-results is after network evaluation only. To create a labeled video, make sure you run `deeplabcut.analyze_videos` first; this will produce a h5 data file along the video.

Hi, I did analyze the videos first before trying to create video, but I'm not sure what new file(s) were produced since there's nothing else in the "videos" folder besides the original video I am testing.

When I try to create the labeled video after, I choose the original video that is in the videos folder but I'm not sure if I'm supposed to choose something else from the other folders (dlc-models, evaluation-results, etc.)  since there were no other video files created- just labeled images and csv/h5 text files. Am I supposed to run the original video along with the h5 text file? If so, the h5 text files are in evaluation-results, labeled-data, and training-datasets folders.

@millerlabUCSD - indeed you should choose the same video as you picked when you ran "analyze videos." on that tab, you also have the option to check the box "filter predictions". Then on the create video tab, you can check use filtered, etc. Can you check the folder with your "original" video? you should see something like this, i.e. an .h5, a .meta alongside your original video:

![Screen Shot 2021-03-14 at 10 06 55 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28102185/111084221-9bd07400-8511-11eb-9c74-2a5766b00cb2.png)

issue.title: corrupt video frames and "no unfiltered file found" errors

repository.name: DeepLabCut
repository.description: Official implementation of DeepLabCut: Markerless pose estimation of user-defined features with deep learning for all animals incl. humans

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
There have been a number of issues and forum entries reported errors following apparently completed video analysis. Users report "No unfiltered data file found" type errors (e.g.: #1141) even though DLC reports "Analysis completed".

While there are other causes of this error (e.g. [moving projects between computers](https://forum.image.sc/t/extract-outlier-frames-gui-unable-to-find-analysed-video/49354/11?u=backyardbiomech), or user error in not including tracking method in multi-animal projects), some or most of the errors appear to be caused by corrupted video files or frames, and based on screenshots of the folders containing the targeted videos, `dlc.analyze_videos` simply didn't save any files. 

OpenCV somewhat infamously lacks robustness working with corrupted video files that will play without problems in most media players which suggests the file is uncorrupted. [Re-encoding video files with ffmpeg](https://forum.image.sc/t/analyzing-new-videos-no-data/48313) typically fixes the error, but DeepLabCut (and opencv) provide no warning. In fact, from my own experience, the only indication of a problem while running `dlc.analyze_videos` is that the progress bar stops prematurely. Even in those cases, there is no traceback, the "success" message is still printed, and no output files are actually saved.

It appears in [`predict_videos.py`](https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/blob/0f24d32ac57cc1cc0bc60bf8a307211779d736fd/deeplabcut/pose_estimation_tensorflow/predict_videos.py#L419) that the strategy is to create data frames of zeros, and then to continue over corrupted frames by simply not writing data to that row. But in some cases, no data file ends up being saved. I'm hypothesizing that some forms of corruption, probably in the header/metadata, are more fatal so this frame skipping method doesn't work. But it's not clear why no traceback is produced.

I think a relatively easy (and informative fix) would be a simple print alerting to skipped frames, the possibility of no data file being saved, and the solution of re-encoding the video with ffmpeg.

I'm not at my development computer right now, but I think adding in something like the following would help:
After the `if ret:` [operations](https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut/blob/0f24d32ac57cc1cc0bc60bf8a307211779d736fd/deeplabcut/pose_estimation_tensorflow/predict_videos.py#L435)

```python
elif counter < nframes:
    print("possible corrupt frame encountered...if no .pickle, .meta, or .h5 files are saved for the video, consider re-encoding the video with ffmpeg")
```

Without a `break`, that would allow the analysis to continue in case the corruption is minor enough to allow completion, but would inform the user of the problem. 

Of course, it would print with each skipped frame, so this could get messy. As an alternative, you could set a variable `corrupt_frame=True` in the loop, with a single conditional print instance after the loop. 

If I can find a corrupt video to test on, I'll see if I can test a PR, but it might be a while.

body:
> @millerlabUCSD - indeed you should choose the same video as you picked when you ran "analyze videos." on that tab, you also have the option to check the box "filter predictions". Then on the create video tab, you can check use filtered, etc. Can you check the folder with your "original" video? you should see something like this, i.e. an .h5, a .meta alongside your original video:
> 
> ![Screen Shot 2021-03-14 at 10 06 55 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28102185/111084221-9bd07400-8511-11eb-9c74-2a5766b00cb2.png)

Hi, under the videos file, there is nothing else present besides the original video. Does this mean I missed a step somewhere?
I tried to rerun analyze videos with my original vid and clicked yes to filter the predictions but ran into another error: 

2021-03-15 12:43:18.487417: W tensorflow/core/framework/op_kernel.cc:1401] OP_REQUIRES failed at conv_ops.cc:446 : Resource exhausted: OOM when allocating tensor with shape[8,256,540,960] and type float on /job:localhost/replica:0/task:0/device:GPU:0 by allocator GPU_0_bfc |

as well as 

No unfiltered data file found in C:\Users\vtngo\Desktop for video C2549_Trim and scorer DLC_resnet_50_C2549TrimMar11shuffle1_100000.

Please let me know if I should try something differently since I seemed to not run into any errors until the Analyze/Create Videos portion of the GUI.

![Screenshot (3)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/77994014/111212205-8ea49b00-858c-11eb-90d3-bde170d89a9e.png)

Hi @millerlabUCSD so it says filtered file not found as the video is not analyzing. thanks for the screenshot; here you can see it s**tops at 6%**, which suggests your video is corrupted, at some point the meta data is likely missing. Can you convert your video into another format and try again? 

then as you check plot and filter, it tried to do do those things next, but of course there is no video to filter, and no filtered video found to plot ;).

rename.to: analyze video stops a 6%-- video corrupted

body: ^^ btw, you should also upgrade to the latest DLC, as it will tell you there is an issue, but will finish analyzing your video.

Hi, 

Thank you for being patient with this case and for your quick responses- I really appreciate it!

Let me try to convert it from .mp4 to .avi and see if that helps. 

Additionally, I tried to upgrade to the latest DLC on windows. 
In Anaconda  Prompt I ran:
pip install -U wxPython==4.0.7.post2 

which installed  numpy-1.20.1 successfully. However, I also ran: 
pip install deeplabcut==2.2b8

which is where I was led to an error saying:
"ERROR: Command errored out with exit status 1:" 
" ERROR: Failed building wheel for numpy"
" ERROR: Failed cleaning build dir for numpy"
" Rolling back uninstall of numpy"

What should I do in this case?

The latest version is 2.1.10.2:
To grab the latest master version run

`pip install git+https://github.com/DeepLabCut/DeepLabCut.git`

Hi, 

Just an update but I updated DLC to 2.2b8

Additionally, I converted the video from .mp4 to .avi and the problem is still the same (stops at 6% when analyzing). 

Sorry, I'm not sure where to follow along to post #1105 so I am still stuck. This time around, I only labeled a couple of frames and didn't set as many iterations since I just want to see a successful analysis first. 

I noticed that even in the beginning steps, the video was still corrupted. Do you think I should just try a different video or is there a different problem? 
![Screenshot (6)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/77994014/112395490-bba72b00-8cbb-11eb-9e69-305e099fcdcf.png)

The latest DLC version is no longer the beta version b8, it is 2.1.10.2 as mentioned above.  Note though that the fix for video analysis will only be available in the next release (unless you clone the repo now) 😊

Hmm when I git cloned the repo you posted/upgraded, it did state that the requirement is already up to date (2.1.10.2) but when I checked the version, it still outputs 2.2b8

Is there some way to roll back the beta version?

"(base) C:\Users\vtngo>pip install --upgrade deeplabcut
Requirement already up-to-date: deeplabcut in c:\programdata\anaconda3\lib\site-packages (2.1.10.2)
Requirement already satisfied, skipping upgrade: opencv-python-headless~=3.4.9.33 in c:\programdata\anaconda3\lib\site-packages (from deeplabcut) (3.4.9.33)
Requirement already satisfied, skipping upgrade: tensorpack==0.9.8 in c:\programdata\anaconda3\lib\site-packages (from deeplabcut) (0.9.8)"
You've installed deeplabcut in (base) whereas I suspect you'd like to be in your conda environment; make sure to activate it first before installing packages.

I was able to download  2.1.10.2 and it seems like I have a new problem (not enough memory available?)
Any suggestions on how to allocate more memory? When I run nvidia-smi, I can't see the GPU memory storage as it is N/A. 


![Screenshot (12)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/77994014/113364532-a4de8500-9308-11eb-9272-5fe498e296f6.png)

![Screenshot (10)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/77994014/113364132-92178080-9307-11eb-8d40-6b9821813ed9.png)

![Screenshot (13)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/77994014/113364834-609fb480-9309-11eb-8189-72ebd65bcac2.png)

issue.title: Analyze_videos runs into video error partway into analysis

repository.name: DeepLabCut
repository.description: Official implementation of DeepLabCut: Markerless pose estimation of user-defined features with deep learning for all animals incl. humans

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

issue.body:
I am using my university's linux cluster, accessed on my Mac, deeplabcut/2.0-p3.68-tf1.14 I created a pbs and py file to run analyze_videos through the cluster. The first few videos work fine, but after that there is an error that the file is not found, and the script stops running. But all of the videos are the same mp4 files, collected on the same camera/stored in the same folder, same everything. Here is how a correct video analysis looks:
